sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The &app; application is a Unicode/ISO10646 character map and font viewer. Unicode/ISO10646 is a coded character set and character set standard. The Unicode/ISO10646 developers intend to include in this character set all of the characters that are used in all of the written languages in the world.

You can use &app; to select characters from a character table, then combine the characters into a text string with standard characters. You can insert the text string that you create into other applications, such as text editor documents.
&app; provides accented characters, mathematical symbols, special symbols, and punctuation marks. Many of the characters provided by &app; are not available on a standard keyboard.

sect2.title: To Start &app;
sect2.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Accessories Character Map.
Execute the following command: gnome-character-map
For more information about how to run &app; from a command line, see gnome-character-map 1.

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.
The &app; window contains the following elements:

listitem.para: The menus on the menubar contain most of the commands that you need to work with &app;.
The toolbar contains a drop-down list of fonts, font style buttons, and a zoom spin box.
The display area contains the following components:
Script or Unicode Block list box
Character Table tabbed section
Character Details tabbed section
Text to copy text box
Copy button
The statusbar displays information about the selected character.

sect2.title: To Change the Character-Set List
sect2.para: To list the character sets by script name, choose View By Script .
To list the character sets by Unicode block, choose View By Unicode Block .

sect2.title: To Create a Text String
sect2.para: To create a text string in the Text to copy field, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select a character set from the list box.
Insert characters in one of the following ways:
Double-click on a character button in the Character Table tabbed section, to insert the character in the Text to copy field.
Click on a character button in the Character Table tabbed section, then press Return to insert the character in the Text to copy field.
Click on a character button in the Character Table tabbed section, then drag the character to the Text to copy field.

Click on the Text to copy field to give focus to the field. If a text string is already in the field, click on the text string at the point where you want to insert the character. Press a character key on your keyboard to insert that character into the field.

sect2.title: To Copy and Paste Your Text String into an Application
sect2.para: To copy and paste the text string from the Text to copy field into an application, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Drag the pointer to select the text string in the Text to copy field, and click Copy. The selected text string appears highlighted.

Point to the location in an application where you want to put the text string and middle-click to insert the text string. You can also paste the text string into the application if a Paste facility is available. You can repeat the insertion as many times as you want while the text string is selected. Click on the Text to copy field to deselect the text string.

sect2.para: When you paste the contents of the Text to copy field into other applications, the text string appears in the current character set of the application.
If your text string contains non-visible characters, you can only insert the text string into applications that support the full character set.
If you quit &app; before you paste the text string into an application, your text string is lost.

sect2.title: To Change the Input Mode
sect2.para: To change the input mode, right-click on the Text to copy field, then select Input Methods.
To display character layout options that are useful for working with non-Latin character sets, right-click on the Text to copy field, then select Insert Unicode Control Character.

sect2.title: To Search for a Character
sect2.para: To search for a character, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Choose Search Find .
Enter the character in the Search field in the Find dialog.
Click Find.
&app; highlights the first character that matches the search criteria, in the Character Table tabbed section. &app; also displays the Unicode code point and Unicode character name in the status bar.
If no matching character is found, &app; displays an information alert.
Choose Search Find Next to find the next matching character.
Choose Search Find Previous to find the previous matching character.

sect2.title: To Display the First Character in the Clipboard
sect2.para: To display the first character in the clipboard, choose Go Character in Clipboard .
&app; highlights the character in the Character Table tabbed section. &app; also displays the Unicode code point and Unicode character name in the status bar.

sect2.title: To Browse Through all Characters
sect2.para: You can browse through the characters in the Character Table tabbed section in the following ways:

listitem.para:
Choose Go Next Character
to select the next character in the Unicode sequence.

Choose Go Previous Character
to select the previous character in the Unicode sequence.
Press the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Use the Character Table scrollbar.
Press the Page Up and Page Down keys to browse through the characters page by page.
Press the Home key to select the first character in the Unicode sequence. To select the last character, press the End key.

sect2.title: To Display Detailed Information About a Character
sect2.para: To display detailed information about a character, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select a character set from the list box. Example: Basic Latin
Select a character from the Character Table tabbed section. Example: B
Click on the Character Details tabbed section.

sect2.para: The Character Details tabbed section displays the following information about the selected character:

listitem.para: Unicode code point
Example: U+0042
Unicode character name
Example: LATIN CAPITAL LETTER B
Unicode category
Example: Letter, Uppercase
UTF-8 encoding
Example: 0x42
Octal escaped UTF-8 encoding
Example: \102
Decimal entity reference
Example: B
Example: U+212C SCRIPT CAPITAL B
Click on the link to display the details for the referenced character.

Choose Go Back
to navigate back through the link history.

Choose Go Forward
to navigate forward through the link history.

sect2.title: To Change the Format of a Character
sect2.para: To change the format of a character, perform the following steps:

listitem.para: To change the font, select a font from the font drop-down list.
To change the font type to bold type, click on the Bold button.
To change the font type to italic type, click on the Italic button.

To make the font size larger, choose
View Zoom In
or use the zoom spin box.

To make the font size smaller, choose
View Zoom Out
or use the zoom spin box.
To magnify the selected character, press Shift.

sect2.title: To Change the Format of the Character Table
sect2.para:
To change the format of the character table, choose
View Snap Columns to Power of Two .

&app; changes the Character Table tabbed section so that the number of columns is a power of two, for example, two columns, four columns, eight columns, and so on. The number of columns depends on the size of the window and the size of the font.
